data.Notes: An identical version of this proposal passed both chambers in the 2019-20 session, but was invalidated after the Department of State failed to advertise the proposed amendment as required. The legislature has advanced a similar House proposal this session, restarting the process.

OpenStatesInfo.title: A Joint Resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, further providing for courts to be open and suits against the Commonwealth.

actions.description: Re-referred to RULES AND EXECUTIVE NOMINATIONS

data.Status: Waiting for a vote in the Senate
data.WhatWouldItDo: Create a two-year window for victims of childhood sexual abuse to file civil suits

data.Notes: An identical version of this proposal passed both chambers in the 2019-20 session. This session's proposal was approved by the House, poised for a vote in the Senate, and on track to appear on the May 2021 ballot. But because the Department of State failed to follow the proper advertisement procedures, it was no longer eligible to appear on the ballot. The House voted on this proposal again to restart the process. Now, an identical version of this proposal must pass in the 2023-24 session.

data.Status: Waiting for a vote in the Senate
data.WhatWouldItDo: Eliminate the separate ballot or column for judicial retention elections

data.Notes: Originally, this bill proposed to change how Pennsylvania's lieutenant governor is selected. An identical version passed the House and Senate in the 2019-20 session, and it passed the Senate in that form again this session. It was then amended in the House to contain four more proposed changes to the constitution, restarting the process. Those changes are now awaiting consideration in the Senate.

OpenStatesInfo.title: A Joint Resolution proposing separate and distinct amendments to the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, further providing for action on concurrent orders and resolutions and for Lieutenant Governor; providing for executive orders; further providing for qualifications of electors; and providing for election audits.

data.Status: Amended and passed in the House, waiting for consideration in the Senate
data.WhatWouldItDo: Expand the General Assembly's power to reject executive orders and regulations; Require government-issued ID to vote; Require the auditor general to audit elections; Change the way the lieutenant governor is selected.

data.Notes: This is an emergency amendment, meaning it would only need to pass in one session, as opposed to two. It was moved after the Department of State failed to properly advertise an identical amendment in time for the May 2021 primary election. On March 22, 2021, the House debated voting on the bill before recessing for the day. The House ultimately adjourned without voting.
